title: The Chemical Brothers
text:
The Chemical Brothers are an English <a href="electronic%20music">electronic music</a> duo formed by Tom Rowlands and Ed Simons in <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a> in 1989. They were pioneers (along with <a href="The%20Prodigy">The Prodigy</a>, <a href="Fatboy%20Slim">Fatboy Slim</a>, <a href="The%20Crystal%20Method">The Crystal Method</a>, and other acts) in bringing the <a href="big%20beat">big beat</a> genre to the forefront of <a href="pop%20culture">pop culture</a>. They released their debut album "Exit Planet Dust" (1995) and it eventually went on to sell over a million copies worldwide. After attracting <a href="Virgin%20Records">Virgin Records</a>, the duo achieved more widespread success with their second album "<a href="Dig%20Your%20Own%20Hole">Dig Your Own Hole</a>" (1997), which topped the <a href="UK%20Albums%20Chart">UK charts</a>. In the UK, they have had six No. 1 albums and 13 Top 20 singles, including two No. 1 hits. 
Their name came about in 1995 after they dropped their original name of "The Dust Brothers" due to the <a href="Dust%20Brothers">existence of a different band with the same name</a>. "The Chemical Brothers" refers to the duo's 1993 groundbreaking "Chemical Beats", which epitomised their genre-defining sound. In the United States, they have won six <a href="Grammy%20Award">Grammy Award</a>s including <a href="Best%20Rock%20Instrumental%20Performance">Best Rock Instrumental Performance</a>, <a href="Best%20Dance%20Recording">Best Dance Recording</a> and <a href="Best%20Dance/Electronic%20Album">Best Dance/Electronic Album</a> of the year as recently as 2020.
History.
1984–1995: Formation and early incarnations.
Ed Simons was born in <a href="Herne%20Hill">Herne Hill</a> on 9 June 1970, the son of a <a href="barrister">barrister</a> mother and a father he has described as "absent". His two main interests when he was young were aeroplanes and musicals. Simons attended two <a href="South%20London">South London</a> public schools, <a href="Alleyn%27s%20School">Alleyn's School</a> and <a href="Dulwich%20College">Dulwich College</a>. During his school years, he developed a fondness for <a href="rare%20groove">rare groove</a> and <a href="hip%20hop%20music">hip hop music</a>, having frequented a club called the Mud Club from the age of 14. By the time he left school, his two main musical interests were the Manchester bands <a href="New%20Order%20%28band%29">New Order</a> and <a href="the%20Smiths">the Smiths</a>. After finishing school with 11 <a href="General%20Certificate%20of%20Education">O</a> levels and three <a href="A%20level">A level</a>s, he continued on to study history, especially late medieval history, at the <a href="University%20of%20Manchester">University of Manchester</a>.
Tom Rowlands was born in <a href="Kingston%20upon%20Thames">Kingston upon Thames</a> on 11 January 1971. When he was very young, his family relocated to <a href="Henley-on-Thames">Henley-on-Thames</a>. He later attended <a href="Reading%20Blue%20Coat%20School">Reading Blue Coat School</a> in <a href="Berkshire">Berkshire</a>. In his early teens, his interest in music broadened to other genres. Initially, some of his favourites included the "<a href="Oh%2C%20What%20a%20Lovely%20War%21">Oh, What a Lovely War!</a>" soundtrack, <a href="2%20Tone%20%28music%20genre%29">2 Tone</a>, the nascent <a href="gothic%20rock">gothic rock</a> genre (<a href="The%20Sisters%20of%20Mercy">The Sisters of Mercy</a>, <a href="Fields%20of%20the%20Nephilim">Fields of the Nephilim</a>) and the <a href="Electro%20%28music%29">electro</a> sounds of artists such as <a href="Kraftwerk">Kraftwerk</a>, <a href="New%20Order%20%28band%29">New Order</a>, <a href="Cabaret%20Voltaire%20%28band%29">Cabaret Voltaire</a>, and <a href="Heaven%2017">Heaven 17</a>. He described the first <a href="Public%20Enemy">Public Enemy</a> album "<a href="Yo%21%20Bum%20Rush%20the%20Show">Yo! Bum Rush the Show</a>" as "the record that probably changed his life", and commented that "Miuzi Weighs a Ton" was "one of the most amazing tracks he had ever heard". Rowlands also started collecting <a href="Hip%20hop%20music">hip hop</a> records by artists like <a href="Eric%20B">Eric B</a> and <a href="Schoolly%20D">Schoolly D</a>. Rowlands left school with similar accomplishments to Simons, achieving nine O levels and three A levels. He went on to study history at the University of Manchester, where he met Simons in 1989. Rowlands chose Manchester primarily to immerse himself in its music scene in general and the <a href="Fac%2051%20Hacienda">Fac 51 Hacienda</a> in particular.
Rowlands was also in a band called Ariel prior to meeting up with Simons. He formed Ariel in London with friends Brendan Melck and Mathew Berry. Their first single was "Sea of Beats", which was essentially a <a href="white%20label">white label</a>. Before Philip Brown set up Echo Logik Records, their first promo was "Bokadilo". Other songs, released on <a href="Gramophone%20record">12-inch</a>, included "Mustn't Grumble" and their most well-known, "Rollercoaster". After a year on Echo Logik they signed to the <a href="record%20label">record label</a> <a href="Deconstruction%20Records">deConstruction</a>. They insisted on a female singer and they recruited former Xpansions frontwoman <a href="Sally%20Ann%20Marsh">Sally Ann Marsh</a>, and after some disappointing songs like "Let It Slide" (Rowlands would later describe it as "a stinker"), the band fell apart. One of the last things Ariel did was the song "T Baby" which was remixed by the pair. In regards to the remix, Ed stated that "Ariel symbolically ended when Deconstruction asked us for a <a href="Dust%20Brothers">Dust Brothers</a> remix of an Ariel track. That was the final nail in the coffin."
Rowlands and Simons started to <a href="Disc%20jockey">DJ</a> at a club called "Naked Under Leather" in the back of a pub in 1992, under the alias, "The 237 Turbo Nutters" (named after the number of their house on Dickenson Road in Manchester and a reference to their Blackburn <a href="Rave%20culture">raving</a> days). The pair would play hip hop, <a href="Techno%20music">techno</a>, and <a href="House%20music">house</a>. The two called themselves the Dust Brothers after <a href="Dust%20Brothers">the US production duo</a>, famous for their work with the <a href="Beastie%20Boys">Beastie Boys</a>. After a while, Rowlands and Simons began to run out of suitable <a href="instrumental%20hip%20hop">instrumental hip hop</a> tracks to use, so they started to make their own. Using a <a href="Hitachi%2C%20Ltd.">Hitachi</a> <a href="hi-fi">hi-fi</a> system, a computer, a <a href="Sampler%20%28musical%20instrument%29">sampler</a>, and a keyboard, they recorded "Song to the Siren", which sampled <a href="This%20Mortal%20Coil">This Mortal Coil</a>. "Song to the Siren" was released on their own record label, which they called Diamond Records (after Ed's nickname). At this point the Dust Brothers were the first-ever backroom DJ's in the Sumptuous Locarno Lounge at The Job Club in Gossips night club in <a href="Dean%20Street%2C%20Soho">Dean Street, Soho</a> from April 1992 till April 1993. 
In October 1992, they pressed 500 white-label copies and took them to various dance record shops around London, but none would play it, saying that it was too slow (the track played at 111 <a href="beats%20per%20minute">BPM</a>). They sent a copy to London DJ <a href="Andrew%20Weatherall">Andrew Weatherall</a>, who made it a permanent fixture in his DJ sets. In May 1993, Junior Boy's Own released "Song to the Siren".
Around June 1993, the Dust Brothers recorded their first <a href="remix">remix</a>es. The first was "Packet of Peace" for <a href="Justin%20Robertson">Justin Robertson</a>'s <a href="Lionrock">Lionrock</a> group, followed by songs from <a href="Leftfield">Leftfield</a>, <a href="Republica">Republica</a>, and <a href="the%20Sandals">the Sandals</a>. Later in 1993, Rowlands and Simons completed work on their "<a href="Fourteenth%20Century%20Sky">Fourteenth Century Sky</a>" <a href="Extended%20play">EP</a>, released in January 1994. It contained the groundbreaking "<a href="Chemical%20Beats">Chemical Beats</a>", which epitomised the duo's genre-defining <a href="big%20beat">big beat</a> sound. The <a href="EP%20%28music%20CD%29">EP</a> also contained "One Too Many Mornings", which for the first time showed their less intense, more chilled-out side. Both "One Too Many Mornings" and "Chemical Beats" would later appear on their debut album. "Fourteenth Century Sky" was followed later in 1994 by the "<a href="My%20Mercury%20Mouth%20EP">My Mercury Mouth EP</a>". "Chemical Beats" was also part of the soundtrack for the first edition of the "<a href="Wipeout%20%28game%29">Wipeout</a>" video game series, having been featured in "Wipeout" for the <a href="PlayStation%20%28console%29">PlayStation</a> in 1995.
In October 1994, the Dust Brothers became resident DJs at the small, but influential <a href="Heavenly%20Recordings%23The%20Social">Heavenly Sunday Social Club</a> at the Albany pub in London's <a href="Great%20Portland%20Street">Great Portland Street</a>. <a href="Noel%20Gallagher">Noel Gallagher</a>, <a href="Paul%20Weller%20%28singer%29">Paul Weller</a>, <a href="James%20Dean%20Bradfield">James Dean Bradfield</a>, and <a href="Tim%20Burgess%20%28musician%29">Tim Burgess</a> were regular visitors. The Dust Brothers were subsequently asked to remix tracks by <a href="Manic%20Street%20Preachers">Manic Street Preachers</a> and <a href="The%20Charlatans%20%28British%20band%29">the Charlatans</a>, plus <a href="Primal%20Scream">Primal Scream</a>'s "Jailbird" and <a href="the%20Prodigy">the Prodigy</a>'s "<a href="Voodoo%20People">Voodoo People</a>". These two remixes received television exposure, being playlisted by <a href="MTV">MTV</a> Europe's "The Party Zone" in 1995. 
Early in 1994, the Dust Brothers were approached in the club one Sunday by Gallagher, from <a href="Oasis%20%28band%29">Oasis</a>, who at the time were becoming one of the most prominent guitar bands in Britain. Gallagher told the duo that he had a <a href="Balearic%20beat">Balearic</a>-inspired track he had written that he would like them to remix. However, over time, Gallagher changed his mind, and in the end the Brothers did not remix it.
In March 1995, the Dust Brothers began their first international tour, which included the United States – where they played with <a href="Orbital%20%28band%29">Orbital</a> and <a href="Underworld%20%28band%29">Underworld</a> – then a series of European festivals. Also around this time, objections were filed by <a href="Dust%20Brothers">the original Dust Brothers</a> over the use of their name, and so Rowlands and Simons had to decide on a new name. They decided to call themselves The Chemical Brothers after "Chemical Beats" (Simons' grandmother had suggested they call themselves "The Grit Brothers").
In June 1995, they released their fourth single, the first under their new identity. "Leave Home" was released on Junior Boy's Own, as a preview of the imminent debut album and became the band's first chart hit, peaking at No. 17.
1995–1998: "Exit Planet Dust" and "Dig Your Own Hole".
In July 1995, the Chemical Brothers released their debut album "<a href="Exit%20Planet%20Dust">Exit Planet Dust</a>" (the title inspired by their name change) on Freestyle Dust/Junior Boy's Own. It entered the UK charts at No. 9 and featured guest vocalist <a href="Beth%20Orton">Beth Orton</a> on the song "Alive Alone". It eventually went on to sell over a million copies worldwide, and was used on the soundtrack of the <a href="science%20fiction">science fiction</a> TV series pilot "<a href="Virtuality%20%28TV%20series%29">Virtuality</a>". Shortly after its release, the Chemical Brothers signed to <a href="Virgin%20Records">Virgin Records</a>, to which they took their own offshoot label, Freestyle Dust. For their next single, "<a href="Life%20Is%20Sweet%20%28song%29">Life Is Sweet</a>", released in September 1995, they again used a guest vocalist, featuring their friend Tim Burgess, singer of the Charlatans. It reached No. 25 in the UK Singles Chart. The single was also "Select" magazine's "Single of the Month" for October. The release included a <a href="Daft%20Punk">Daft Punk</a> remix of "Life Is Sweet".
<a href="The%20Stone%20Roses">The Stone Roses</a> asked the duo to remix "Begging You", from their "<a href="Second%20Coming%20%28The%20Stone%20Roses%20album%29">Second Coming</a>" album. After beginning work on a remix which they viewed as having potential, they later rejected the idea and the work was cancelled.
In October 1995, the duo returned to the Heavenly Sunday Social for a second and final run of DJ dates. They then became residents of Heavenly Social on Saturdays at Turnmills and also in Liquid Rooms in Tokyo. In November, the Chemical Brothers played the <a href="Astoria%20Theatre">Astoria Theatre</a> in London. At this time the Brothers usually used a fusion of "Chemical Beats" and <a href="the%20Beatles">the Beatles</a>' "Tomorrow Never Knows" as their encore. During the encore, however, <a href="Keith%20Flint">Keith Flint</a> from the Prodigy jumped up on stage to dance, wearing a T-shirt sporting the slogan "Occupation: mad bastard". A few from the crowd subsequently joined in. This resulted in a power cable being kicked loose, bringing the show to a temporary close. The Chemical Brothers confessed to not being too bothered; "because he's Keith from The Prodigy, and he can do whatever the fucking hell he likes". Just before Christmas 1995, they played their biggest gig to date, with the Prodigy, at the <a href="Brixton%20Academy">Brixton Academy</a>.
In January 1996, "Exit Planet Dust" was certified gold. The Chemical Brothers released their first new material in six months on Virgin, the "Loops of Fury" EP. The four-track release was limited to 20,000 copies, but is now available for digital download. It entered the UK charts at No. 13. "<a href="NME">NME</a>" described the lead track as "splashing waves of synths across hard-hitting beats". The EP also contained a Dave Clarke remix of "Chemical Beats", and two other new tracks, "Get Up on It Like This" and "(The Best Part Of) Breaking Up".
In February 1996, "Select" magazine published a list of the 100 best albums of the 1990s thus far. "Exit Planet Dust" was listed at Number 39. In August 1996, the Chemical Brothers supported Oasis at <a href="Concerts%20at%20Knebworth%20House">Knebworth</a>, where 125,000 people attended each of the two shows.
During the 1995 <a href="Glastonbury%20Festival">Glastonbury Festival</a>, Rowlands and Simons had another conversation with <a href="Noel%20Gallagher">Noel Gallagher</a>. Gallagher told them how much he liked "Exit Planet Dust", and asked if he could sing on a future track, similar to the way <a href="Tim%20Burgess%20%28musician%29">Tim Burgess</a> had worked on "Life Is Sweet". They did not think much of the offer at the time, given how busy Gallagher would be with the release of Oasis' "<a href="%28What%27s%20the%20Story%29%20Morning%20Glory%3F">(What's the Story) Morning Glory?</a>", plus the complexities of dealing with each other's record companies. However, the duo later worked on a track which they thought would benefit from having a vocal on it. They sent Gallagher a tape of what they had done so far. He worked on it overnight, and left a message with them early the next morning that he was ready to record it. The track was called "<a href="Setting%20Sun%20%28The%20Chemical%20Brothers%20song%29">Setting Sun</a>" and was finally released in October 1996. It entered the UK charts at the top, giving the duo their first ever Number One single. "Setting Sun" was backed by a longer instrumental version, and also a new track "Buzz Tracks", which was not much more than a DJ tool. The three remaining members of the Beatles' lawyers later wrote to the Chemical Brothers, mistakenly claiming that they had sampled "<a href="Tomorrow%20Never%20Knows">Tomorrow Never Knows</a>". Virgin Records hired a <a href="Musicology">musicologist</a> to prove that they did not sample the song.
Meanwhile, in 1996, "<a href="Live%20at%20the%20Social%20Volume%201">Live at the Social Volume 1</a>" was released by <a href="Heavenly%20Records">Heavenly Records</a>, which became the Chemical Brothers' first mix CD (excluding "Xmas Dust Up", a free album that came in a 1994 issue of "NME"). It was also the duo's first live album (excluding the EP "<a href="Live%2005">Live 05</a>").
In March 1997, the Chemical Brothers released the second track from their forthcoming album. "<a href="Block%20Rockin%27%20Beats">Block Rockin' Beats</a>" went straight to No. 1 in the UK, possibly thanks, this time, to its <a href="Schoolly%20D">Schoolly D</a> vocal sample and re-working of the bass-line from <a href="23%20Skidoo%20%28band%29">23 Skidoo</a>'s single "Coup". The "NME" named it "Single of the Week" and said "It throbs like your head might if you had just done a length underwater in a swimming pool full of <a href="Alkyl%20nitrites">amyl</a>." It later won them a <a href="Grammy%20Award">Grammy Award</a> for <a href="Best%20Rock%20Instrumental%20Performance">Best Rock Instrumental Performance</a>.
In the US at this time, "Setting Sun" was sitting at Number 80 in the Billboard Top 100, after selling around 80,000 copies, an uncommon achievement for a European "dance" act. Sales from "Exit Planet Dust" were also around 150,000.
On 7 April 1997, the Chemical Brothers released their second album, "<a href="Dig%20Your%20Own%20Hole">Dig Your Own Hole</a>". It was recorded at the band's own south London studio, with the title taken from graffiti on the wall outside. The album was well received, with "Mixmag" rating it 10/10 and calling it "mad enough to be thrilling, slick enough for not even remotely trendy coffee tables".
During the summer of 1997, the Chemical Brothers toured extensively, particularly in the United States. In August, the Chemical Brothers achieved a rapprochement with the US Dust Brothers, and asked them to remix the forthcoming single "<a href="Elektrobank">Elektrobank</a>". They themselves also became highly sought-after for remixes for other artists. In September, the next single from "Dig Your Own Hole", "Elektrobank" was released. In November, the pair played at Dublin's Point Theatre, with support from <a href="Carl%20Cox">Carl Cox</a>. They also began a US tour in Detroit.
At the end of the year, "Dig Your Own Hole"s final track, the nine-minute-long "The Private Psychedelic Reel", gave rise to a limited-edition mini-EP of the same name. The <a href="B-side">B-side</a> consisted of a live version of "Setting Sun", recorded at the <a href="A%20Campingflight%20to%20Lowlands%20Paradise">Lowlands Festival</a>, Netherlands on 24 August 1997. Also in December, following four sold-out US shows, the Chemical Brothers toured the UK, concluding in a sold-out show at Brixton Academy, London.
In 1998, they concentrated more on DJing, although some remixes did see the light of day, including "I Think I'm in Love" from <a href="Spiritualized">Spiritualized</a>. Both a vocal remix and an instrumental remix were included in the single release. Each clocked in at over seven-and-a-half minutes. Another remix completed by the Chemical Brothers was "Delta Sun Bottleneck Stomp" by <a href="Mercury%20Rev">Mercury Rev</a>. This was another extension in the association between the two bands, since Mercury Rev's Jonathon Donahue contributed to "The Private Psychedelic Reel" on "Dig Your Own Hole".
In September 1998, a second mix album, "<a href="Brothers%20Gonna%20Work%20It%20Out">Brothers Gonna Work It Out</a>", was released. It contains some of their own tracks and remixes, as well as songs from artists who have influenced their sound, such as <a href="Renegade%20Soundwave">Renegade Soundwave</a>, <a href="Meat%20Beat%20Manifesto">Meat Beat Manifesto</a>, Carlos "After Dark" Berrios, and <a href="Kenny%20%27Dope%27%20Gonzales">Kenny 'Dope' Gonzales</a>.
1999–2002: "Surrender" and "Come with Us".
In May 1999, the Chemical Brothers played three UK dates, their first since December 1997. Also that month, they released their first new original material in two years, a track called "<a href="Hey%20Boy%20Hey%20Girl">Hey Boy Hey Girl</a>". This was more <a href="house%20music">house</a>-influenced than big beat. In interviews at the time, Rowlands and Simons indicated that the track was inspired by nights out at Sheffield club Gatecrasher. The track was also one of their more commercially accessible tracks and went to number 3 in the UK charts.
Their third album, "<a href="Surrender%20%28The%20Chemical%20Brothers%20album%29">Surrender</a>", was released in June 1999. It featured vocals from Noel Gallagher, Mercury Rev's <a href="Jonathan%20Donahue">Jonathan Donahue</a>, and <a href="Mazzy%20Star">Mazzy Star</a>'s <a href="Hope%20Sandoval">Hope Sandoval</a>. As "Hey Boy Hey Girl" had suggested, the album was more house-oriented than the previous two. On one of the album's stand out tracks, "Out of Control", <a href="New%20Order%20%28band%29">New Order</a>'s <a href="Bernard%20Sumner">Bernard Sumner</a> supported by <a href="Primal%20Scream">Primal Scream</a>'s <a href="Bobby%20Gillespie">Bobby Gillespie</a> provided vocals. It reached No. 1 in the UK album charts. The <a href="Michel%20Gondry">Michel Gondry</a>-directed <a href="music%20video">music video</a> for "<a href="Let%20Forever%20Be">Let Forever Be</a>", which utilised ground-breaking video and film effects in its depiction of a young woman's nightmares, also received a lot of attention.
Later that summer, the Chemical Brothers performed at the <a href="Woodstock%20%2799">Woodstock '99</a> concert on 24 July, with positive reception. They later headlined the <a href="Glastonbury%20Festival">Glastonbury</a> dance tent on the Friday night, followed by a UK tour which ended in December and included <a href="Homelands%20%28festival%29">Homelands</a> Scotland on 4 September. In November, "Out of Control", featuring Sumner and Gillespie on vocals, was released as a single. The release also contained the <a href="Sasha%20%28DJ%29">Sasha</a> remix. The final single from "Surrender", in February 2000, was the five track "Music: Response" EP, containing the title track and two remixes, plus <a href="Electronic%20Battle%20Weapon">Electronic Battle Weapon</a> 4, named "Freak of the Week", and a track called "Enjoyed", which was essentially a remix of "Out of Control" by the Chemical Brothers themselves. A CD copy of "Surrender" was placed in the third "<a href="Blue%20Peter">Blue Peter</a>" <a href="time%20capsule">time capsule</a>, buried in January 2000. That same month, they appeared on Primal Scream's album "<a href="Xtrmntr">Xtrmntr</a>" at track 11 with a remix.
In June 2000, they played the Pyramid stage at the Glastonbury Festival. In August 2000 they played to a large crowd at the main stage at Creamfields festival, Ireland. In December 2000, the Chemical Brothers aired one of their new tracks, "It Began in Afrika" at their New York DJ gigs, supporting <a href="U2">U2</a>.
In 2001, they were active with releases and live performances. Early in the year, they began working on a fourth album, provisionally titled "Chemical Four". The first track which fans got a taste of was "It Began in Afrika", as previously played in their DJ set in New York. The track would make its live debut in California in April 2001, at the <a href="Coachella%20Valley%20Music%20and%20Arts%20Festival">Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival</a>. Another new track, "Galaxy Bounce", also got its public debut at Coachella. As had become customary for their releases and experiments, "It Began in Afrika" was first pressed as a promo, as part of the "<a href="Electronic%20Battle%20Weapon">Electronic Battle Weapon</a>" series. It received much airplay on dance music radio shows in the UK, and became more and more popular in clubs over the course of the summer. It also became one of the "anthems" in Ibiza as the summer progressed. It was given a full commercial single release in September, reaching No. 8 in the UK singles chart, even though no promotional video was made for the track.
Rowlands and Simons also remixed a track from <a href="Fatboy%20Slim">Fatboy Slim</a>'s "<a href="Halfway%20Between%20the%20Gutter%20and%20the%20Stars">Halfway Between the Gutter and the Stars</a>", entitled "Song for Shelter". This remix was released as a single on 3 September 2001 (one week before "It Began in Afrika") as the CD2 single for "<a href="Song%20for%20Shelter%20/%20Ya%20Mama">Song for Shelter / Ya Mama</a>". It reached No. 30 in the UK Singles Charts (sales were combined with the CD1 single).
The Chemical Brothers finished work on another album, "<a href="Come%20with%20Us">Come with Us</a>", in October 2001. It featured collaborations with <a href="Richard%20Ashcroft">Richard Ashcroft</a> of <a href="the%20Verve">the Verve</a> ("The Test"), and long-time collaborator <a href="Beth%20Orton">Beth Orton</a> ("The State We're In"). The album was released in January 2002, preceded by a single, "Star Guitar", a melodic <a href="Balearic%20beat">Balearic beat</a> number, with a promotional video by <a href="Michel%20Gondry">Michel Gondry</a> that featured passing scenery synchronised to the beat viewed through a train window. What would be the second track on the album, "It Began in Afrika", was released 10 September 2001 to be circulated around the clubbing scene where it was a popular hit. "Star Guitar" was also released as a <a href="DVD">DVD</a> single, the pair's first. "Come with Us", was less well received than their previous albums, but nonetheless went straight to No. 1 in the UK Albums Chart in the first week of its release, selling 100,000 copies. In April, the title track from the album was released as a single with remixes by <a href="Fatboy%20Slim">Fatboy Slim</a> as part of a double A-sided release with "The Test".
During the summer of 2002, the Chemical Brothers travelled the festival circuit to promote the album. Later in 2002, they released two EPs, one specifically aimed at Japan and the other the US (entitled "<a href="AmericanEP">AmericanEP</a>"). Both contained remixes, live versions and B-sides. Additionally, the band produced <a href="New%20Order%20%28band%29">New Order</a>'s "<a href="Here%20to%20Stay%20%28New%20Order%20song%29">Here to Stay</a>", written for the film "<a href="24%20Hour%20Party%20People">24 Hour Party People</a>" and released as a single to promote the soundtrack, and remixed the song as well. One of their other major songs from this album was "Galaxy Bounce", which was popular and featured as the main title music for the <a href="Xbox%20%28console%29">Xbox</a> game "<a href="Project%20Gotham%20Racing%20%28video%20game%29">Project Gotham Racing</a>". It was also included on the soundtrack for the movie "". "Star Guitar" was featured as a song on the <a href="PlayStation%20Portable">PlayStation Portable</a>'s "<a href="Lumines%20II">Lumines II</a>".
Two other songs, "Come with Us (Introduction)" and "<a href="Star%20Guitar">Star Guitar</a> (Title Screen)", were featured on a <a href="PlayStation%202">PlayStation 2</a> racing game titled "WRC II: Extreme". Both songs are instrumental. The song "My Elastic Eye" from the album "Come with Us" was played in the 2004 film "<a href="The%20Butterfly%20Effect">The Butterfly Effect</a>" starring <a href="Ashton%20Kutcher">Ashton Kutcher</a> and <a href="Amy%20Smart">Amy Smart</a>.
2003–2006: "Push the Button".
Early 2003 saw Rowlands and Simons back in the studio working on new material, including "The Golden Path", a collaboration with <a href="Wayne%20Coyne">Wayne Coyne</a> of <a href="the%20Flaming%20Lips">the Flaming Lips</a>. This was released in September 2003, at the same time as a "best of" album, entitled "<a href="Singles%2093%E2%80%9303">Singles 93–03</a>", marking ten years of the Chemical Brothers' releases. "Singles 93–03" included most, but not all, of their singles. A second new track, in addition to "The Golden Path", was included on the album, called "Get Yourself High". "Singles 93–03" was also released on DVD, with extra features including selected live performances and interviews with Rowlands, Simons, and many of their collaborators from throughout the period. "Get Yourself High", which featured Canadian rapper <a href="k-os">k-os</a> on vocals, was released as a single in November 2003.
In late 2003 and 2004, the Chemical Brothers continued to work in the studio on new material and a remix of "<a href="Slow%20%28Kylie%20Minogue%20song%29">Slow</a>" by <a href="Kylie%20Minogue">Kylie Minogue</a>. After being released on rare white label vinyl, it was subsequently given a commercial release in March on CD (on her next single "Red Blooded Woman") and on 12-inch vinyl picture disc (containing two other Minogue remixes). In Summer 2004 they returned to the festival circuit, including appearances at the <a href="Glastonbury%20Festival">Glastonbury Festival</a>, Tokyo, Scotland, and Ireland. They also visited South America for the second time (the first time being in 1999), arriving at Chile, Argentina, and Brazil. It was during these sets that they played new material, including "Acid Children", which proved to be one of the most popular new tracks.
In September 2004, the Chemical Brothers released the seventh "Electronic Battle Weapon". "Electronic Battle Weapon 7" was being released as a one-sided promo-only 12-inch, containing "Acid Children". A marked departure from the Chemical Brothers' previous musical endeavours, it featured a screeching 303 bassline and a distinctive vocal sample; a pitch-altered vocal sample proclaiming "You Are All My Children Now!", which is lifted from the horror film "". It was coupled with the projection of a sinister clown mouthing these same words at their live gigs.
The "Electronic Battle Weapon" series of promo releases have typically been newly recorded Chemical Brothers tracks, released on promo to allow DJs to test them in a club environment, and to gauge their popularity.
In 2004, the Chemical Brothers began work on "<a href="Push%20the%20Button%20%28The%20Chemical%20Brothers%20album%29">Push the Button</a>", their fifth studio album, which features collaborations with <a href="Tim%20Burgess%20%28musician%29">Tim Burgess</a>, <a href="Kele%20Okereke">Kele Okereke</a>, and <a href="Anwar%20Superstar">Anwar Superstar</a>, amongst others. The album was released on 24 January 2005.
"<a href="Galvanize%20%28song%29">Galvanize</a>", which features rapper <a href="Q-Tip%20%28rapper%29">Q-Tip</a> on vocals, was the first single to be taken from "Push the Button", and premiered on <a href="iTunes">iTunes</a>. The single was released on 17 January 2005, and entered the UK chart at No. 3. The second single, "<a href="Believe%20%28Chemical%20Brothers%20song%29">Believe</a>" (featuring <a href="Kele%20Okereke">Kele Okereke</a> from <a href="Bloc%20Party">Bloc Party</a>), failed to crack the top 10, but still made it into the top 20, peaking at No. 18. "The Boxer", featuring Tim Burgess, became the duo's first single to fail to crack the top 40.
The album and single "Galvanize" won a Grammy at the <a href="Grammy%20Awards%20of%202006">Grammy Awards of 2006</a>. One of the songs in this album, "The Big Jump", appears in the video game "<a href="Burnout%20Revenge">Burnout Revenge</a>", as well as "<a href="Project%20Gotham%20Racing%203">Project Gotham Racing 3</a>". The track "Surface to Air" features a pulsing chord progression and bassline reminiscent of the intro to <a href="The%20Strokes">The Strokes</a> song "The Modern Age".
An unofficial, remixed version of the album entitled "Flip the Switch" was released as a free download, along with the "Believe" EP, featuring six further remixes of "Believe".
In September 2006, the Chemical Brothers were revealed as the first musicians to be involved in Tate Tracks. <a href="Tate%20Modern">Tate Modern</a> invited various groups and songwriters to choose a work that inspired them from the gallery's collection of modern art and then write a track about it. The Chemical Brothers' submission, "Rock Drill", was inspired by the <a href="Jacob%20Epstein">Jacob Epstein</a> sculpture "<a href="Rock%20Drill%20%28Jacob%20Epstein%29">Torso in Metal from The Rock Drill</a>", and could be heard on headphones in front of the work in the gallery. From October 2006, it also became available to hear online at the Tate Tracks website.
2007–2009: "We Are the Night".
The Brothers announced in June 2006 on their official web forum that the duo had been working on new material, specifically an album, code-named "Chemical 6". Simons also wrote that the band would be playing select venues in the Summer 2007 season, specifying Rome, and also <a href="Fabric%20%28club%29">Fabric</a> in London. Simons was also quoted as saying that the duo were "hoping to put a battle weapon out for the summer", possibly referring to the Electronic Battle Weapon series, the somewhat experimental tracks the band occasionally released on <a href="white%20label">white label</a>.
"Electronic Battle Weapon 8" and "9" were debuted on <a href="Pete%20Tong">Pete Tong</a>'s <a href="BBC%20Radio%201">BBC Radio 1</a> show on 8 December 2006. The double-sided vinyl was finally released just before the Chemical Brothers' much anticipated New Year's Eve gig at the famous <a href="Turnmills">Turnmills</a> in London. The vinyl had a limited edition release worldwide and was received well by fans, DJs, and critics alike. "Electronic Battle Weapon 8", at about six and a half minutes, was very distinct from the "big acid" style that the earlier "Electronic Battle Weapons" adhered to. It was characterised by 'thundering' drums with a rising synth line. A version of this track featured on the "We Are the Night" album and was entitled "Saturate". "Electronic Battle Weapon 9" was a typical Chemicals dancefloor track with their trademark <a href="vocoder">vocoder</a> vocals coupled with sirens and a basic 'tribal' melody.
At the same <a href="Turnmills">Turnmills</a> gig, the Brothers also played a previously unreleased song at midnight to welcome 2007, which went down well with the crowd. This track eventually emerged as "Burst Generator", found on the forthcoming album "We Are the Night". Many were left wondering if the latest in the Electronic Battle Weapon series were simply one-off experiments or signalled a new direction they could take with the new album, perhaps swaying from their genre defining big beat albums of the past. The song was also the band's 100th released song.
On 21 March 2007, the Chemical Brothers officially announced their forthcoming album on <a href="MySpace">MySpace</a>. The new album, entitled "<a href="We%20Are%20the%20Night%20%28album%29">We Are the Night</a>", was released on 2 July 2007 in the United Kingdom and 17 July 2007 in the United States. The Chemical Brothers cited a delay in the production of artwork for this delay. EMI subsequently released an online Chemical Brothers computer game as an apology. The track listing was released on the official mailing list on 10 April. Collaborations featured heavily on the album, including <a href="Klaxons">Klaxons</a> ("All Rights Reversed"), <a href="Midlake">Midlake</a> ("The Pills Won't Help You Now"), <a href="Ali%20Love">Ali Love</a> ("<a href="Do%20It%20Again%20%28The%20Chemical%20Brothers%20song%29">Do It Again</a>"), and <a href="Willy%20Mason">Willy Mason</a> ("Battle Scars").
On 12 April 2007, <a href="Pete%20Tong">Pete Tong</a> again had the privilege of giving the world the very first preview of a Chemicals track. This time it was the first single "Do It Again" off their new album, aired on his <a href="BBC%20Radio%201">BBC Radio 1</a> "In New Music We Trust" show. The official release of the single was 4 June (digital download) and 14 June (12-inch, 7-inch and CD). The album went on general release in the UK on 2 July 2007.
In September 2007, the Chemical Brothers played a free live gig in Trafalgar Square as part of the Becks Fusions event. All who attended were provided with 3D glasses to view the on-screen visual effects.
The Chemical Brothers supplied a new track for the "<a href="Heroes%20%28U.S.%20TV%20series%29">Heroes</a>" soundtrack, titled "Keep My Composure". An alternate version of this track was released on "<a href="Brotherhood%20%28The%20Chemical%20Brothers%20album%29">Brotherhood</a>", the duo's second singles compilation, which also featured the new single "<a href="Midnight%20Madness%20%28song%29">Midnight Madness</a>" and a second disc of every Electronic Battle Weapon released to date. The Chemical Brothers continued to tour into 2008 to promote the collection, including a landmark date at <a href="Olympia%20London">Olympia London</a>.
2010–2012: "Further", "Hanna" and "Don't Think".
On 30 March 2010, the band announced on their website that their seventh studio album, titled "<a href="Further%20%28The%20Chemical%20Brothers%20album%29">Further</a>", would be released on 22 June and would be "the band's first to be released with corresponding films made specifically to match each of the 8 audio tracks." The films were made with long-time visuals collaborators <a href="Adam%20Smith%20%28director%29">Adam Smith</a> and Marcus Lyall. Before the release of the album, the band played four shows in May at the London Roundhouse where they played the album and its accompanying films in their entirety. The films were released on a special edition DVD and on the iTunes LP edition.
Most reviews were positive, with <a href="BBC%20Music">BBC Music</a> declaring that "... synths are brutally manhandled and pushed to their limits across the eight tracks". "<a href="The%20Irish%20Times">The Irish Times</a>" reported that "This is a very impressive collection that is carried along with a stirring sense of velocity and momentum". However, praise was not unanimous for the album, with the American rock magazine "Spin" giving it a rating of three out of five stars.
At the <a href="New%20York%20Comic%20Con">New York Comic Con</a>, on 10 October 2010, film director <a href="Joe%20Wright">Joe Wright</a> announced that the Chemical Brothers would be scoring the soundtrack to his forthcoming film, "<a href="Hanna%20%28film%29">Hanna</a>". Wright, who had worked with the Chemical Brothers in the past as a member of the visual company Vegetable Vision, stated that he was "very excited to finally ... work with a more modern beat. There's a lot of bass, it's very loud." The <a href="Hanna%20%28soundtrack%29">soundtrack</a> was released on iTunes on 15 March 2011 and on CD on 4 July 2011.
The duo also contributed a new version of the song "<a href="Further%20%28The%20Chemical%20Brothers%20album%29">Don't Think</a>" titled "Nina Frequency", as well as two new songs "Electric Hands" and "Danka Jane", to the soundtrack of the 2010 film "<a href="Black%20Swan%20%28film%29">Black Swan</a>" directed by <a href="Darren%20Aronofsky">Darren Aronofsky</a>. All three songs have not been released.
The Chemical Brothers released their first concert film, "<a href="Don%27t%20Think">Don't Think</a>", in 2012, documenting their performance at <a href="Fuji%20Rock%20Festival">Fuji Rock Festival</a> in Japan in 2011. The film debuted in February in theaters around the world, including a premiere in London where attendees – including <a href="Matt%20Smith">Matt Smith</a>, <a href="Karen%20Gillan">Karen Gillan</a> and <a href="Keira%20Knightley">Keira Knightley</a> – were seen dancing in aisles and seats, leading one reviewer to remark "at times it was impossible to tell which 'hands in the air' were on screen and which were in the room." The film was the first concert film to be mixed in 7.1 surround sound, and was released on Blu-ray, DVD, and CD on 26 March 2012.
On 7 March 2012, it was announced that the Chemical Brothers would be scoring their second film soundtrack, for the bank heist film "<a href="Now%20You%20See%20Me%20%28film%29">Now You See Me</a>", but the band had to pull out of the project in the early stages due to scheduling conflicts.
2012–2017: Rowlands' solo work and "Born in the Echoes".
After "Hanna" and "Don't Think", Tom Rowlands worked on a number of solo projects. He remixed and produced music for <a href="Tinie%20Tempah">Tinie Tempah</a>, <a href="The%20Klaxons">The Klaxons</a>, <a href="I%20Break%20Horses">I Break Horses</a>, and <a href="New%20Order%20%28band%29">New Order</a>, scored the film "<a href="Trespass%20Against%20Us">Trespass Against Us</a>" starring <a href="Michael%20Fassbender">Michael Fassbender</a> and <a href="Brendan%20Gleeson">Brendan Gleeson</a> and directed by longtime visual collaborator and film and television director Adam Smith, and the theatrical production of "<a href="Life%20of%20Galileo">Life of Galileo</a>" directed by Joe Wright performed at the <a href="Young%20Vic">Young Vic</a>, and released 12-inch single "Through Me / Nothing but Pleasure" on <a href="Erol%20Alkan">Erol Alkan</a>'s label <a href="Phantasy%20%28record%20label%29">Phantasy</a> in May 2013.
On 21 October 2014, the Chemical Brothers released a single "<a href="This%20Is%20Not%20a%20Game">This Is Not a Game</a>", which was created for "", featuring <a href="Miguel%20%28singer%29">Miguel</a> and <a href="Lorde">Lorde</a>. In December 2014, they announced an appearance at the 2015 <a href="S%C3%B3nar">Sónar</a> festival and a new album, scheduled for release in 2015. 
In April 2015, videos containing animation and audio loops appeared on the official Chemical Brothers <a href="Facebook">Facebook</a> page and website, thechemicalbrothers.com, ahead of the imminent release of new music. On 23 April, their new song "Sometimes I Feel so Deserted" premiered on <a href="BBC%20Radio%201">BBC Radio 1</a>. On 17 July, the duo released "<a href="Born%20in%20the%20Echoes">Born in the Echoes</a>", their eighth album. Singles from this album included "Go"; an up-beat reunion with guest vocalist <a href="Q-Tip%20%28musician%29">Q-Tip</a> and director <a href="Michel%20Gondry">Michel Gondry</a> and "Wide Open" in collaboration with <a href="Beck">Beck</a>. <a href="St.%20Vincent%20%28musician%29">St. Vincent</a>, <a href="Ali%20Love">Ali Love</a>, and <a href="Cate%20Le%20Bon">Cate Le Bon</a> also feature on the album.
Along with the new album announcement, it was revealed that Simons would "take a break" from touring to focus on unspecified <a href="academic%20work">academic work</a>. Adam Smith filled in for him on stage during the 2015 tour. During the tour, Simons attended a few shows as an audience member, and both he and Rowlands expressed concern in interviews that this could mark a permanent retirement. The first concert without Simons was performed at Siemens Arena in Lithuania. Smith continued to fill in through the end of 2015, most notably at <a href="Glastonbury%20Festival">Glastonbury</a> and the <a href="Apple%20Music%20Festival">Apple Music Festival</a>, and uniquely controlled both lights and music from the stage.
Simons returned to live performances in 2016, performing at the <a href="Parklife%20%28festival%29">Parklife Festival</a> in Manchester, which included a new setlist and a cover of New Order's "<a href="Temptation%20%28New%20Order%20song%29">Temptation</a>" with Sumner's recorded vocals. In November 2016, the duo released the non-album single "C-H-E-M-I-C-A-L", which premiered on BBC Radio 1. The song originally debuted as a demo in 2012, created to open the duo's DJ sets from 2012 to 2015.
2018–present: "No Geography".
On 10 January 2018, the Chemical Brothers confirmed production of their ninth album, "<a href="No%20Geography">No Geography</a>", via <a href="Instagram">Instagram</a> and other social media platforms. They released their first song in three years on 28 September 2018, titled "Free Yourself", from the forthcoming album.
On 7 March 2019, <a href="Formula%201">Formula 1</a> announced a collaboration with the Chemical Brothers, which was released the next day in the form of the song "We've Got To Try".
The Chemical Brothers' ninth studio album, "<a href="No%20Geography">No Geography</a>", was released on 12 April 2019 to positive reviews. In 2020, the album won three <a href="Grammy%20Awards">Grammy Awards</a> including Best Dance/Electronic Album, Best Dance Recording, and Best Music Video.
In 2019, international festival the Berlin Music Video Awards elected "We've Got to Try" the winner of the Best Director category and also as the overall winner - Best Music Video. The Chemical Brothers' music video for "Eve of Destruction" reached second place at the Berlin Music Video Awards 2020 for Best Art Director (Ollie Tong).
Live.
The Brothers have also played at major festivals, including <a href="Glastonbury%20Festival">Glastonbury</a>, <a href="Fuji%20Rock%20Festival">Fuji Rock</a>, <a href="Vive%20Latino">Vive Latino</a>, <a href="HFStival">HFStival</a> and the <a href="Reading%20Festival">Reading</a> and <a href="Leeds%20Festival">Leeds</a> festivals. In addition to performing their own music, they also hold regular DJ nights where they mix other artists' tracks (in the style of "Brothers Gonna Work It Out").
